skill.name: writing-data
skill.description: Use this skill when you need to structure data in `srs/data` for the Next.js app
skill.summary: Use this skill when you need to structure data in `srs/data` for the Next.js app
skill.author: Emz1998

security_audit.summary: Static analyzer flagged markdown inline code syntax (backticks) and the word 'data' as security concerns. After evaluation, these are false positives - the file contains only markdown documentation with no actual code execution or cryptographic algorithms. Risk factor reflects markdown parsing patterns only.

medium_findings.title: Markdown Backtick Syntax Flagged
medium_findings.description: Static analyzer detected backtick patterns on lines 3 and 8. These are markdown inline code formatting, not shell/Ruby command execution.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: Backticks are markdown syntax for inline code formatting (e.g., `srs/data`). No command execution occurs.

medium_findings.title: Word 'Data' Flagged as Cryptographic
medium_findings.description: Static analyzer flagged 'data' as a weak cryptographic algorithm pattern.
medium_findings.confidence_reasoning: File contains only markdown text. Word 'data' refers to information/file content, not cryptographic functions.

content.value_statement: Organizing scattered data files is challenging and leads to maintenance issues. This skill provides clear guidelines for structuring data in the srs/data directory following modular principles for cleaner, more maintainable code.
actual_capabilities: Guides data file organization in srs/data directory
Enforces modular file structure with 50 line limit
Helps separate data into focused, manageable files
limitations: Does not generate data files automatically
Does not validate data format or structure
Requires existing srs/data directory to exist
Skill does not execute code or modify files directly

use_cases.title: New Project Data Setup
use_cases.description: Organize initial data files when starting a new feature module in a Next.js project
use_cases.target_user: Developers setting up new data modules

use_cases.title: Refactoring Large Data Files
use_cases.description: Split oversized data files into smaller, focused files following modular principles

use_cases.title: Team Codebase Standardization
use_cases.description: Ensure consistent data organization across team members working on the same Next.js project

prompt_templates.title: Basic Data Placement
prompt_templates.prompt: Use the writing-data skill to structure the data in srs/data for my Next.js app. I have a file called data.ts that needs organizing.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-File Organization
prompt_templates.prompt: Use writing-data to restructure my srs/data folder. Currently all my data is in one large file but I want to split it by feature.

prompt_templates.title: Modular Restructuring
prompt_templates.prompt: Apply the writing-data skill to my project. I need to reorganize srs/data following the 50-line limit and single-data-per-file rule.

prompt_templates.title: Project-Specific Conventions
prompt_templates.prompt: Use writing-data to help me structure data files in srs/data for my Next.js app. Follow these project conventions: [describe your conventions].

output_examples.input: I have a large data.ts file with 200+ lines containing user preferences, app settings, and feature flags all mixed together.
output_examples.output: Split the data into focused files: user-preferences.ts (user settings), app-settings.ts (configuration), feature-flags.ts (feature toggles). Each file contains one logical data domain following the 50-line limit.

output_examples.input: My srs/data folder has a mix of TypeScript files, JSON files, and even some YAML files all in the root directory.
output_examples.output: Organize by type: create folders for typescript/, json/, yaml/. Keep related data together and ensure each file serves a single purpose with clean, focused content.

best_practices: Keep each data file under 50 lines by splitting logically related content
Create one file per data domain rather than bundling multiple concerns
Follow existing project naming conventions for consistency
anti_patterns: Putting unrelated data types in the same file
Ignoring file size limits resulting in hard-to-maintain files
Mixing data formats (JSON, YAML, TypeScript) without organization

faq.question: What file types does this skill support?
faq.answer: The skill works with any data file types including TypeScript, JSON, and YAML. It focuses on organization rather than format-specific handling.

faq.question: Does this skill create new files?
faq.answer: No, this skill provides guidance and instructions for organizing data. It does not modify files or create new ones directly.

faq.question: What is the 50-line limit based on?
faq.answer: The 50-line limit promotes readability and maintainability. Files larger than this often indicate mixed concerns that should be separated.

faq.question: Can I use this skill with existing data files?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill helps you reorganize existing data by providing structure guidelines you can apply to your current files.

faq.question: Does this skill validate data content?
faq.answer: No, the skill focuses on file organization and structure, not data validation or format checking.

faq.question: What if my project has different conventions?
faq.answer: The skill provides flexible guidelines. You can adapt the principles to match your existing project conventions and requirements.
